title: 106_hr2651
content: The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act includes provisions such as eliminating restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements, exceptions to ownership referral prohibitions, and changes in the definition of group practice. It also delays the implementation of ownership referral changes until final regulations are promulgated and excludes certain medical devices from the referral restrictions. Additionally, it permits pathologists who are independent contractors to supervise clinical laboratory services. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act eliminates restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act eliminates restrictions on physician referrals based on compensation arrangements. Section 1877 of the Social Security Act is amended to clarify ownership or investment interests in entities through equity. The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act removes limitations on physician referrals related to compensation arrangements. Section 1877 of the Social Security Act is revised to specify ownership and investment interests in entities through equity. Amendments include changes to subsections (d), (f), and the removal of subsection (e). The Physician Self-Referral Amendments of 1999 Act removes limitations on physician referrals regarding compensation arrangements and specifies ownership and investment interests in entities through equity. Amendments include changes to subsections (d), (f), and the removal of subsection (e). In subsection (h), paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) are struck, and rules for faculty are revised. SEC. 3. EXCEPTIONS TO OWNERSHIP REFERRAL PROHIBITIONS. Revisions to Exception for In-Office Ancillary Services include repealing the site-of-service requirement and defining general supervision for individuals under a physician in the group practice. The physician (or group practice) is legally responsible for services performed by individuals, ensuring licensure and certification requirements are met. Amendments clarify treatment of physician owners of group practices. Conforming amendment relates to ancillary services furnished personally. Amendments clarify treatment of physician owners of group practices regarding ancillary services furnished personally or through group practice. Exception for services furnished in a rural area now requires not less than 75 percent instead of "substantially all". The definition of group practice under the Social Security Act is amended to include physicians who are owners or bona fide employees of the group. Implementation of 1993 ownership referral changes is delayed until final regulations are issued. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1993 amendments do not apply to referrals made before final regulations are issued. Exclusion of intraocular lenses, eyeglasses, and contact lenses from Social Security Act. Pathologists can supervise clinical laboratory services as independent contractors. Section 1877(b)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to include pathologists supervising clinical laboratory services in a group practice. The effective date for the amendments is the date of enactment, regardless of regulations being in place.
